facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 594 of 1960 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 6, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 6 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 594 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgement and order dated March 6, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 6 of 1958.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on March 13, 1963 by AYYANGAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March, 13. The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR J.-The facts necessary to appreciate the points involved in this appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Punjab are briefly these.

facts.text: Sham Singh, respondent No. 2, effected a registered deed of usufructuary mortgage dated March 6, 1933 of land measuring 7530 Kanals and 19 Marlas in village Mohanpur, District of Multan in Pakistan to the father of appellants 1 to 3 and to Topan Das, father of the 4th appellant.

anchor.surface_text: By a registered deed of mortgage dated March 6, 1933 Sham Singh who is respondent No. 2 before us effected an usufructuary mortgage of land measuring 7530 Kanals and 19 Marlas situate in village Mohanpur in the District of Multan  number in Pakistan  to the father of appellants 1 to 3 and to Topan Das--the father of the 4th appellant.

facts.text: The sum secured by the 1933 mortgage was Rs. 30,000.

anchor.surface_text: The sum secured by the mortgage was Rs. 30,000/-. The stipulation in the mortgage was that the income derived from the properties transferred to the possession of the mortgagees was to be treated as interest on Rs. 10,000/- out of the principal sum and that the balance of Rs. 20,000/- was to carry a sum of Rs. 1,650/- per annum as interest.

facts.text: The mortgage deed fixed a term of 10 years beyond which the mortgagee could sue for recovery of the mortgage-money.

anchor.surface_text: The stipulation in the mortgage was that the income derived from the properties transferred to the possession of the mortgagees was to be treated as interest on Rs. 10,000/- out of the principal sum and that the balance of Rs. 20,000/- was to carry a sum of Rs. 1,650/- per annum as interest. The deed further fixed a term of 10 years beyond which the mortgagee companyld sue for the recovery of the mortgage-money.

facts.text: About 4 years after the mortgage, Sham Singh sold a major portion of the mortgaged property consisting of about 6,568 Kanals of land to Guranditta Ram and others.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to the deed of mortgage, about 4 years thereafter, the mortgagor-Sham Singh sold a major portion of the mortgaged property companysisting of about 6,568 Kanals of land to Guranditta Ram and others. Out of the companysideration for this sale a sum of Rs. 26,500/- was left with the transferee the same being directed to be paid in discharge of the mortgage.

facts.text: Out of the consideration for the sale to Guranditta Ram, Rs. 26,500 was left with the transferee to be paid in discharge of the mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the companysideration for this sale a sum of Rs. 26,500/- was left with the transferee the same being directed to be paid in discharge of the mortgage. The Sale to Guranditta Ram was subject to a preemption claim and pre- emptor exercised his rights to obtain that relief.

facts.text: Narain Singh, father of Pratap Singh (1st respondent), was the pre-emptor and obtained a decree for sale on February 16, 1940 by virtue of his right of preemption.

anchor.surface_text: Narain Singh-father of Partap Singh, the 1st respondent-was the preemptor and in a suit filed by him he obtained on February 16, 1940 a decree for sale in his favour by virtue of his right of preemption and in pursuance of this decree he obtained symbolical possession of the land, the mortagees still companytaining to retain the actual possession of the land.

facts.text: Narain Singh obtained symbolical possession of the pre-empted land, while mortgagees retained actual possession.

anchor.surface_text: Narain Singh-father of Partap Singh, the 1st respondent-was the preemptor and in a suit filed by him he obtained on February 16, 1940 a decree for sale in his favour by virtue of his right of preemption and in pursuance of this decree he obtained symbolical possession of the land, the mortagees still companytaining to retain the actual possession of the land.

facts.text: The sum of Rs. 26,500 retained with the vendee was not paid to the mortgagees, leaving the entire mortgage-money outstanding.

anchor.surface_text: The sum of Rs. 26,500/-retained with the vendee under the sale by Sham Singh was number paid over to the mortgagee and thus the entire amount of the mortgage-money remained outstanding.

facts.text: The country was partitioned in 1947 and both the mortgagor (Sham Singh) and mortgagees moved to India as displaced persons.

anchor.surface_text: While things were in this state, the companyntry was partitioned in 1947 and both the mortgagor as well as the mortgagees moved into India and they were displaced persons .

facts.text: Owners (Sham Singh and pre-emptor vendee) were allotted agricultural land in India based on original holdings in Pakistan under Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The owners of the property, viz., the original mortgagor- respondent No.2 Sham Singh and the pre-emptor-vendee were, as displaced persons, allotted agricultural land in India on the basis of their original holdings in Pakistan in pursuance of the relevant rules under the Displaced Persons  Compensation and Rehabilitation  Rules.

facts.text: Appellants (mortgagees) were put in possession in June-July 1950 of properties allotted to Sham Singh and Pratap Singh (legal rep of pre-emptor) totaling 51 standard acres and 9 units (37.4 to resp1, 14.5 to resp2).

anchor.surface_text: The appellants as the mortgagees entitled to possession of the lands were in June-July 1950, under these rules put in possession of the properties allotted to both Sham Singh-the original mortgagor as well as of Pratap Singh-the legal representative of the deceased pre-emptor  respondent No. 1 . The total extent of land which the respondent had been put in possession was 51 standard acres and 9 units of land made up of 37.4 standard acres as being the property belonging to the pre-emptorvendee  respondent No. 1  and 14.5 standard acres by virtue of the property allottable to Sham Singh the original mortgagor  respondent No. 2 .

facts.text: Displaced Persons (Debts Adjustment) Act, 1951 (Act LXX of 1951) was enacted in November 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Union Legislature enacted in November, 1951 the Displaced Persons  Debts Adjustment  Act, 1951  Act LXX of 1951  which we shall hereafter refer to as the Act, being an Act to make provisions for the adjustment and settlement of debts due by displaced persons.

facts.text: Sham Singh and Pratap Singh made separate applications under s.5 of the 1951 Act for adjustment of debts, which were consolidated and heard by Senior Sub-judge, Karnal (Tribunal).

anchor.surface_text: Sham Singh as well as Pratap Singh made separate applications under s. 5 of the Act seeking to obtain the benefit of the settlement and adjustment provision companytained in its s. 16. The two applications were, in view of their having reference to the same mortgage debt, companysolidated and were heard to ether by the Senior Sub-judge, Karnal who was the relevant Tribunal under the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal overruled objections by mortgagee-appellants and scaled down the mortgage debt under s.16.

anchor.surface_text: Several objections were raised by the mortgagee-appellants to these applications but they were overruled and the mortgage debt was scaled down under s. 16 and other relevant statutory provisions which were applicable in the manner we shall detail later.

facts.text: Appeal from Tribunal decision to Punjab High Court was dismissed by Single Judge.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was preferred from this decision to the High Court of Punjab but the same was dismissed by the learned Single judge.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal to Punjab High Court Bench was dismissed in limine, certificate refused, special leave granted by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: A further appeal under the Letters Patent to a Bench of the High Court was dismissed in limine and a certificate of fitness being refused, the appellants applied to this Court for special leave and this being granted, the appeal is number before us.

facts.text: Both appellants and respondents are displaced persons as defined in the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We might add that it is companymon ground that both the appellant and the respondents are displaced persons as defined in the Act.

facts.text: Mortgage was with possession, and appellants allotted lands in India in lieu of lands possessed in West Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: It was also companymon ground that the mortgage in favour of the appellant was with possession. It ought to be mentioned that it wasby virtue of provisions on the lines of the opening words of sub-s.  4  companytained in the rules and executive orders which were in force in 1950, that the appellant was put in possession of the 37.4 and 14.5 standard acres belonging respectively to Pratap Singh and Sham Singh.

facts.text: Tribunal scaled down total mortgage debt of Rs.51,700 to Rs.7,420 based on proportion of allotted land (51 std acres / 359 std acres).

anchor.surface_text: The total mortgaged land number belonging to the petitioner  Pratap Singh  and respondent No. 5  Sham Singh  has been assessed as equivalent to 359 standard acres 14-3/4 units  329 standard acres 13-3/4 units of the petitioner plus 22 standard acres 6-1/2 units of the respondent No. 5  and in lieu thereof the mortgagors have been given in all 51 standard acres 9 units  37.4 to the petitioners and 14.5 to the respondent No. 5 . As provided under s. 16  4  of the Act the amount of the debt payable to respondents 1 to 4 has been reduced in the same proportion in which the land has been allotted to the mortgagors. For the land belonging to them the mortgage debt amounting to Rs. 51,700/- when reduced to this proportion companyes approximately to Rs. 7,420/-.

facts.text: Total mortgaged land assessed as equivalent to 359 standard acres 14-3/4 units (329 std acres 13-3/4 for Pratap Singh + 22 std acres 6-1/2 for Sham Singh).

anchor.surface_text: The total mortgaged land number belonging to the petitioner  Pratap Singh  and respondent No. 5  Sham Singh  has been assessed as equivalent to 359 standard acres 14-3/4 units  329 standard acres 13-3/4 units of the petitioner plus 22 standard acres 6-1/2 units of the respondent No. 5  and in lieu thereof the mortgagors have been given in all 51 standard acres 9 units

facts.text: Appellants argued that Pratap Singh is not a debtor under s.2(6) due to no contractual relationship.

anchor.surface_text: The first companytention raised before us was that Pratap Singh---the representative of the purchaser of the equity of redemption-was number a debtor within s. 2  6 , because there was numbercontractual relationship between him and the displaced creditor i. e., the appellants.

facts.text: Court held that the mortgage contains a covenant by mortgagor to repay after 10 years, entitling mortgagee to sue for recovery.

anchor.surface_text: because the mortgage of 1933 in favour of the appellant companytains a companyenant on the part of the mortgagor to repay the debt after 10 years and in companysequence the mortgagee was entitled to file a suit ... for the recovery of his debt and realise it from the sale of the mortgaged property
Appeal by special leave from the judgement and order dated March 6, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 6 of 1958.

The Union Legislature enacted in November, 1951 the Displaced Persons  Debts Adjustment  Act, 1951  Act LXX of 1951  which we shall hereafter refer to as the Act, being an Act to make provisions for the adjustment and settlement of debts due by displaced persons.

arguments.court_reasoning: They qualify as displaced debtors; mortgage debt covered under s.16(4); applications competent under s.5

arguments.claim: Provisions of s.16(4) apply as mortgage is with possession of agricultural lands in West Pakistan allotted equivalent lands in India

anchor.surface_text: It was also common ground that the mortgage in favour of the appellant was with possession. It ought to be mentioned that it was by virtue of provisions on the lines of the opening words of sub-s.(4) contained in the rules

arguments.claim: s.2(6) definition of debt to be read not in isolation but harmoniously with s.16 which specifically covers usufructuary mortgages

anchor.surface_text: the expression pecuniary liability in s. 2(6) has to be understood not in isolation but with reference to other provisions of the Act and particularly s. 16.

arguments.claim: Every usufructuary mortgage is a debt under the Act for scaling down under s.16 regardless of personal liability

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that every usufructuary mortgage, whatever its nature, is within the definition of debt under the Act for the purpose of scaling down under s. 16

arguments.claim: Liability under mortgage debt can only be scaled down in a suit for redemption filed by the creditor, not by debtor's application under s.5
arguments.court_reasoning: s.5(1) expressly enables debtor to apply for adjustment of debts; s.16 applies to such proceedings

arguments.court_reasoning: Standard acres computation under rehabilitation rules reflects value by accounting for income yield, irrigation etc.; value in proviso contemplates such determination

arguments.claim: Mortgage debt scaled down proportionally based on standard acres allotted vs equivalent left behind (51/359)

anchor.surface_text: The total mortgaged land now belonging to the petitioner Pratap Singh and respondent No. 5 Sham Singh has been assessed as equivalent to 359 standard acres 14-3/4 units (329 standard acres 13-3/4 units of the petitioner plus 22 standard acres 6-1/2 units of the respondent No. 5)

arguments.court_reasoning: Procedure accords with proviso as standard acres equate value per rules

arguments.claim: Rajkumari Kaushalya Devi v. Bawa Pritam Singh holds mortgage-debt within s.2(6) definition

anchor.surface_text: In this connection we might refer to the decision of this Court in Rajkumari Kaushalya Devi v. Bawa Pritam Singh(1), where it was ruled that a mortgage-debt was within the definition of the word 'debt' in s. 2(6) of the Act.

holdings.text: Every usufructuary mortgage, whatever its nature, is within the definition of debt under the Act for the purpose of scaling down under s. 16 and it is wholly immaterial whether or not the creditor is entitled to proceed personally against the debtor.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that every usufructuary mortgage, whatever its nature, is within the definition of debt under the Act for the purpose of scaling down under s. 16 and that it is wholly immaterial whether or

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.2(6) 'pecuniary liability' interpreted harmoniously with s.16(4) expressly covering usufructuary mortgages secured on agricultural land; mortgage has repayment covenant post-10 years allowing suit for sale and personal decree; distinguished Punjab Relief Act and Bombay Act cases; approved Rajkumari Kaushalya Devi and Lahori Lal precedents.

holdings.text: A displaced debtor may invoke the jurisdiction of the Tribunal under s.5(1) for scaling down and adjustment of mortgage debt under s.16(4); no merit in contention that only creditor's suit for redemption can effect adjustment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5(1) expressly allows debtor application for adjustment of debts; mortgage debt qualifies under s.16(4); no requirement for creditor election/application when debtor proceeds under s.5.

holdings.text: Scaling down of debt in proportion of standard acres allotted in India to equivalent standard acres of lands left in Pakistan accords with 'value' requirement in proviso to s.16(4), as standard acres computation reflects value per rehabilitation rules accounting for yield, irrigation etc.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rehabilitation rules determine standard acres equivalents reflecting value via income yield, irrigation factors etc.; proviso contemplates such valuation method; Tribunal's 51/359 proportion correct.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.16(4) apply to the mortgage debt here, as secured on agricultural lands in West Pakistan with possession, and mortgagee allotted lands in India in lieu.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore very difficult to appreciate the argument urged on behalf of the appellant that the provisions of sub-s.(4) of s. 16 are not attracted to the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts match s.16(4) description: agricultural lands, West Pakistan, possession mortgage, India allotment to mortgagee; words 'with possession' general, covers all usufructuary mortgages.

holdings.text: The 1933 mortgage contains covenant to repay after 10 years, entitling mortgagee to sue for recovery from sale of property and personal decree against mortgagor under O.34 r.6 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: because the mortgage of 1933 in favour of the appellant contains a covenant on the part of the mortgagor to repay the debt after 10 years and in consequence the mortgagee was entitled

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct reading of mortgage deed terms; distinguishes pure usufructuary lacking covenant.

anchor.surface_text: Lachhman Singh v. Natha Singh 1 , and the other of the Bombay High Court in Manubhai Mahijibhai Patel v. Trikamlal Lakshmidas 2 , turned on the meaning of the expression debt in the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act Act VII of 1934 and it was held that the amount secured by a pure usufructuary mortgage which neither stipulated for the personal liability of the obligor to pay, number companyferred on the obligee the right to recover the amount by the companyrcive machinery of law, companyld number be called a debt in that essence of the companycept of debt companysisted in the personal liability of the obligor which the obligee was entitled to enforce by action.

precedents.cited_proposition: amount secured by a pure usufructuary mortgage without personal liability of the obligor or right to recover by coercive process could not be called a debt under the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act

precedents.citation: Manubhai Mahijibhai Patel v. Trikamlal Lakshmidas 2

anchor.surface_text: and the other of the Bombay High Court in Manubhai Mahijibhai Patel v. Trikamlal Lakshmidas 2 , turned on the meaning of the expression debt in the Punjab Relief of Indebtedness Act Act VII of 1934 and it was held that the amount secured by a pure usufructuary mortgage which neither stipulated for the personal liability of the obligor to pay, number companyferred on the obligee the right to recover the amount by the companyrcive machinery of law, companyld number be called a debt in that essence of the concept of debt companysisted in the personal liability of the obligor which the obligee was entitled to enforce by action. This decision, even apart from the terms of s. 16 of the Act which in terms includes an usufructuary mortgage in the category of a debt for the purposes of the Act, affords little assistance to the appellant before us

precedents.case_name: Manubhai Mahijibhai Patel v Trikamlal Lakshmidas
precedents.cited_proposition: in the absence of an agreement making a mortgagor personally liable, a purchaser of the equity of redemption was not entitled to apply for adjustment of the mortgage debt as it was not his debt under the Bombay Agricultural Debtors Relief Act

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, there is a decision of the High Court of the Punjab in Lahori Lal v. Kasturi Lal 1 , in which the Bench held that a debt as defined in s. 2 6  of the Act number under companysideration was number limited to personal liabilities only. We companysider that the Act has number left the meaning of the expression debt where such debt is secured by a mortgage including an usufructuary mortgage in any manner of doubt, but on the other hand by making specific provision therefore, has put beyond the pale of argument that these are debts which companyld be scaled down under it.

precedents.cited_proposition: a debt as defined in s. 2(6) of the Act was not limited to personal liabilities only

precedents.citation: Rajkumari Kaushalya Devi v. Bawa Pritam Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection we might refer to the decision of this Court in Rajkumari Kaushalya Devi v. Bawa Pritam Singh 1 , where it was ruled that a mortgage-debt was within the definition of the word ,debt in s. 2 6  of the Act. No doubt., that case was number companycerned with the distinction between cases where the creditor has a right to proceed personally against the debtor and cases where he has number, as in the case of a pure usufructuary mortgage, but the decision is useful as indicating that the expression pecuniary liability in s. 2 6  has to be understood number in isolation but with reference to other provisions of the Act and particularly s. 16.

precedents.case_name: Rajkumari Kaushalya Devi v Bawa Pritam Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: a mortgage-debt was within the definition of the word 'debt' in s. 2(6) of the Act
